track.name: Algorithms
track.descriptions: The true test of problem solving: when one realizes that time and memory aren't infinite.

primary_contest.description:
Sign up for 101 Hack 44, an algorithm contest that’s all about speed, accuracy and efficiency. 

You’ll have 120 minutes to solve 5 challenges. Top 10 coders win HackerRank T-shirts. Get your code on and sign up now!

model.haskell_template:
import Control.Applicative
import Control.Monad
import System.IO


main :: IO ()
main = do
    t_temp <- getLine
    let t_t = words t_temp
    let t = read $ t_t!!0 :: Int
    let b = read $ t_t!!1 :: Int
    let f = read $ t_t!!2 :: Int
    let c = read $ t_t!!3 :: Int
    -- your code goes here

getMultipleLines :: Int -> IO [String]

getMultipleLines n
    | n <= 0 = return []
    | otherwise = do          
        x <- getLine         
        xs <- getMultipleLines (n-1)    
        let ret = (x:xs)    
        return ret

          b (Integer/parseInt (t_t 1)) 
          f (Integer/parseInt (t_t 2)) 
          c (Integer/parseInt (t_t 3))

model.erlang_template:
-module(solution).
-export([main/0]).

main() ->

    { ok, [T,B,F,C]} = io:fread("", "~d~d~d~d"),
    % your code goes here
    true.

read_array(0,D) -> [];
read_array(N,D) -> 
	{ok, [X]} = io:fread("", D),
	[X | read_array(N-1,D)].

read_2darray(0,M,D) -> [];
read_2darray(N,M,D) ->
	Q=read_array(M,D),
	[Q | read_2darray(N-1,M,D)].
